Idaho had one of the fastest-growing economies in the country before the recession.
Last year, Idaho's jobless rate peaked at nearly 10 percent.
That number is coming down, but many people are still struggling to find work.
Molly Messick, in Boise, has been following two of them.
It was just before Thanksgiving when I first met Kelly Barker, a single mom in her mid-40s, quick to smile but clearly, worried.
She had been out of work for months, and was nearing the end of her unemployment benefits.
I really, just simply want a job.
I need to work.
I want to work.
At first, she was optimistic when she lost her job as an office administrator for a financial services company.
Then came doubt, and fear.
Two months into it, I'm like, wow, I can't even get an interview.
I started to panic.
Here I am, 46 years old, out of a job, single mom, house payment - all these abilities, and no one wants me.
The months wore on, and her anxiety deepened.
I think when I didn't have enough money for food - like, I started running low on basic things - I think is when it really started to hit me.
By that point, Barker says, she and her 8-year-old daughter were getting by on a daily food allowance of under $5.
Mindful of utility costs, Barker started timing her daughter's showers, and keeping the heat set at 66 degrees.
She began looking for a roommate.
